column1: Santiago de los Caballeros (English: Saint James of the Knights)
column2: also known as Santiago de los Treinta Caballeros (Spanish pronunciation: [sanˈtjaɣo de los ˈtɾeinta kaβaˈʎeɾos]) or simply Santiago
column3: is the second-largest city in the Dominican Republic and the fourth-largest city in the Caribbean. It is the capital of Santiago Province and major metropolis in the north-central region of the country. The city has a total population of 1
column5: 015 inhabitants. Santiago is located approximately 155 km (96 mi) northwest of the capital Santo Domingo with an average altitude of 178 meters (584 ft).

column1: Founded in 1495 during the first wave of European settlement in the New World
column2: the city is the "first Santiago of the Americas". Today it is one of the Dominican Republic's cultural
column3: political
column4: industrial and financial centers. Due to its location in the fertile Cibao Valley it has a robust agricultural sector and is a leading exporter of rum
column6: and cigars. Santiago is known as "La Ciudad Corazón" (the "Heartland City").

column1: The colony originally was located in the San Francisco de Jacagua popularly known as Jacagua
column2: which was founded in 1495
column3: but when it was destroyed by an earthquake it was moved to its current location in 1506. In granting in 1508 the Royal Privilege of Concession de Armas to the Villa de Santiago of Hispaniola
column4: the heraldic emblem that was included in his shield was venerated. The royal decree signed by King Ferdinand as administrator of the kingdoms of his daughter Joanna I of Castile.

column1: The city was devastated by another earthquake on December 2
column2: 1562. The survivors settled on land belonging to Petronila Jáquez of Minaya
column3: adjacent to the Yaque del Norte
column4: which is the current location of the city's river. The domination of the French during the Peace of Basel (which yielded the Spanish part of the island to France in 1795) left its mark on Santiago. During this era Santiago began its modern urban planning. European neoclassicism is represented at the Palace Hall
column6: by a Belgian architect named Louis Bogaert. The Victorian era was the zenith of architecture in the city. Numerous residences were built in this European style
column7: which makes up the historic center of Santiago.

column1: Santiago de los Caballeros has historically been the capital of the country
column2: and was an important strategic city in the Dominican War of Independence. The name of the city
column3: Saint James of the Knights refers to the Hidalgos de la Isabela
column4: a group of knights who had come from La Isabela city to stay in Santiago. When they got back to Spain they put a formal complaint before the king
column5: stating that their horses had been unfairly commissioned as beasts of burden; that their weapons had been appropriated by the Columbus brothers (Diego and Bartolomew); and that they had been made to do manual labor
column6: something considered beneath their station as knights
column7: who were meant to engage only in battle. Sometimes the city is called Santiago de los 30 Caballeros (English: Saint James of the 30 Knights).

column1: Santiago de los Caballeros is located on a hilly terrain in the middle of the Cibao Valley in the Central Region of the Dominican Republic
column2: one of the most fertile lands found in the island. The Yaque del Norte River passes by Santiago which is in between the Cordillera Central and the Cordillera Septentrional
column3: two of the three major mountain ranges on the island of Hispaniola

column1: Santiago features a tropical wet and dry climate under the Köppen climate classification. The average temperature varies little in the city
column2: because the tropical trade winds help mitigate the heat and humidity throughout the year. December and January are the coolest months and July and August are the warmest. Santiago and the rest of the country are in the Caribbean and have a tropical climate
column3: which
column4: when coupled with the city's altitude
column6: causes cloudy conditions to persist through much of the year. While the city lies within the Hurricane belt
column7: Santiago is more sheltered than other parts of the country from hurricanes because of its location in the Cibao Valley.

column2: like most cities and towns in the Cibao valley
column3: benefits from the fertile lands of this region. This makes Santiago de los Caballeros an important area for farming and livestock. Santiago's industrial sector is also one of the most dynamic in the country. It has the concentration of 15% of domestic industries. This means 308 manufacturing companies
column5: 000 people or 12% of the labor of Dominican manufacturing work. The products range from cigars

column1: Santiago is the second-largest city in the Dominican Republic (after Santo Domingo) and currently produces the 2nd highest percentage of the nations GDP. Telecommunications
column2: such as; wireless phones
column3: cable service
column4: internet service and other services are important for the local economy. Tourism
column6: also accounts for a portion of the city's economy.

column1: Santiago has recently experienced an era of rapid growth and development. It has become a city of great importance for the nation and the region's development. The approximate population of Santiago was about 691
column2: 262 inhabitants (as of 2010).

column1: The Cathedral of Santiago was built in 1895 by Onofre de Lora
column2: an architect native to the city.The Hermanos Patiño Bridge is both the largest and oldest bridge in the city connecting the North and South sides of the city of Santiago. Its construction was started by Rafael Leónidas Trujillo and inaugurated in 1962
column3: one year after his death. The bridge is named after the five brothers that died in an effort to end Trujillo's regime and dictatorship in the Dominican Republic in the mid 20th century.  The anti-Trujillo legacy of the Patiño family did not begin with the brothers
column4: but with their father who was killed in 1931 in the first anti-Trujillo insurrection of the Dominican Republic.On a hill overlooking Santiago is a 67 meters (220 ft) high marble monument. Construction of the monument began in 1944 on the orders of then-dictator Rafael Trujillo. He named it the "Trujillo's Monument to Peace"
column5: and was designed by architect Henry Gazón Bona. Trujillo was assassinated in 1961
column6: after which the monument was renamed the "Monument to the Heroes of the Restoration"
column7: in remembrance of the Independence Restoration War of 1863
column8: in which the Dominican Republic regained its independence from Spain.

column1: Gran Arena del Cibao Dr. Oscar Gobaira
Museums in the city include the Museo Folklórico Yoryi Morel which exhibits Santiago's Carnival culture
column2: and displays some garments worn by lechones of Santiago Province in the Carnival
column3: as well as those worn in other provinces. The museum is named after noted Santiago painter Yoryi Morel. Museo del Tabaco or The Tobacco Museum which shows manufacturing methods as well as the effect of the tobacco plantations along the city's history
column4: the Museo Histórico Fortaleza San Luis or Historic San Luis Fort Museum which previously served as a municipal prison.
column5: the Museo de los Héroes de la Restauración or Restoration Heroes Museum is currently under construction and houses a display of pictures from the Restoration War from the 1863–1865 battles between the Dominican Government and the Spanish army. and Centro León which displays elements of the Caribbean and Dominican cultures

column1: Santiago is home of several universities including Pontificia Universidad Católica Madre y Maestra (PUCMM) and Universidad Tecnológica de Santiago (UTESA). Other higher learning institutions present in Santiago are: Universidad Organización & Método (O&M)

column1: Light Rail in Santiago – A Light Rail development in the city's metro area has been proposed. If completed it will be the second city In the nation to have a mass transit system and would be 3.4 miles (5.5 km) longer than the Metro of Santo Domingo. The Light Rail will have 12 stops
column2: its route will be from the Cemetery to the Airport. Construction was scheduled to begin in October 2007 but currently the project has been delayed and on Hold.

column1: Electric "Highway" from Santo Domingo – Santiago's power comes from Puerto Plata
column2: but the government commenced the building of the Electric "Highway" that will feed Santiago electric energy from Santo Domingo's generators. construction started in February 2007.

column1: Parque Central de Santiago The industrialists of Santiago have defended the project since it is considered to be a solution to the lack of green spaces suitable for relaxation in the city. Nevertheless
column2: it has been argued that the granting of contracts for the different phases from this project violate the frame of transparency and legality.In the Strategic Plan of Santiago it is indicated that the construction of the Metropolitan Park would increase the Santiagos green area from its currently 1.1% to 4%.
